ARTICLE.TITLE: Code of silence: Who shot underworld figure Rota Beattie?
ARTICLE.TEXT:
Kirstyn Beattie's husband, Mongrel Mob Aotearoa vice president Rota Beattie, died recently. Five years ago he was shot in the back of the head, but refused to tell police who pulled the trigger.

Rota Beattie died with bullet fragments in his head, five years after he was shot.

The identity of the person who pulled the trigger remains a mystery to police, who’ve never laid charges in connection with the 2015 gangland incident in Christchurch.

Beattie, the vice president of the Mongrel Mob’s Aotearoa chapter, went to his grave last month refusing to co-operate with investigators.

Staff Photographer/Stuff Rota Beattie pictured during a court appearance in 2004.

READ MORE:

* No charges follow investigation into debt collecting firm Ironclad Securities

* Shooting victim a gangster with serious drug convictions

* Head Hunters home raided in Christchurch



The 45-year-old had a seizure at his home, to the north of the city, on July 27, his family says.

He died in Christchurch Hospital, where he’d been on life support, two days later.

His grieving widow, Kirstyn Beattie, believes the shooting – despite the length of time that had passed – contributed to his death.

Iain McGregor/Stuff Kirstyn and Rota Beattie were married for about eight years. They had four children together.

She says she “hates” the gunman and hopes they’re suffering in silence.

“If they aren’t thinking about the consequences of what they’ve done then that’s really sick. They should be feeling it, and they should be sorry.”

Rota Beattie was shot in the back of the head while sitting in the back of a car driving in an industrial area of central Christchurch, shortly after midnight on April 5, 2015.

The gunman was in a following vehicle.

NZ Police/Supplied Rota Beattie was driven to Christchurch Hospital in this blue Subaru, which was later examined by police.

Beattie was driven to Christchurch Hospital’s emergency department by two men about 1.45am.

They sought help for him before leaving.

In the hours prior to the shooting, Beattie was involved in an altercation at Ironclad Securities, a now defunct debt collecting business on Wordsworth St in Sydenham, where the son of senior patched Head Hunters gang member Lyndon Richardson was celebrating his 21st birthday.

At the time, Ironclad Securities was believed to be the Head Hunters’ Christchurch headquarters.

Staff/Stuff Lyndon Richardson was a senior Head Hunters gang member at the time of the shooting.

Richardson was the sole director of the business.

It has long been suspected that a member of the Head Hunters, a rising force in the city’s underworld at the time, shot Beattie, but police have never been able to prove it.

Detectives searched Ironclad Securities and Richardon’s home in the wake of the incident but found no evidence pointing to the identity of the shooter.

This week, Canterbury district crime manager Detective Inspector Greg Murton said Beattie and other possible witnesses refused to cooperate with police.

Staff Photographer/Stuff Police searched Ironclad Securities, a Head Hunters linked debt collecting business, after Rota Beattie was shot.

“This significantly hampered the investigation.”

The case had been “filed”, Murton said, meaning it was no longer being investigated by police.

He wouldn’t comment on the cause of Beattie’s death, which might be subject to a coronial inquiry, other than to say there was “no direct link between the shooting and his death”.

Despite that, Kirstyn Beattie said she remained convinced the bullet fragments that medical professionals were unable to remove from her husband’s head killed him.

IAIN MCGREGOR/STUFF/Stuff Kirstyn Beattie says her late husband, Rota Beattie, was a loyal family man.

The shooting left him permanently deaf in one ear and caused nerve damage that gave rise to tremendous pain in his left leg.

“I remember one time [the pain] was that bad that … he said to me that he wished that he’d died that night.”

Beattie said her husband began having seizures about a month before his death.

On July 27, he was being helped to bed following a “little seizure” when he “smiled at me and then said f… and just passed out”.

Iain McGregor/Stuff Kirstyn Beattie points out her husband in a photo featuring members of the Mongrel Mob’s Aotearoa chapter.

“In my heart I saw him die there. He stopped breathing and changed colour.”

Last week, Rota Beattie was buried wearing his gang patch in a red casket that bore his name.

Mongrel Mob members from around New Zealand travelled to Christchurch for his tangi.

Roads were blocked as his casket was driven from his home to Ruru Lawn Cemetery in Bromley on the other side of town.

Supplied/Stuff Mongrel Mob vice president Rota Beattie's coffin is carried from his home en route to Ruru Lawn Cemetery

“There were people cheering for him. It was just amazing because he deserved that respect,” his wife said.

Rota Beattie, who grew up in Hastings and did jail time for serious drug offending, was a member of the Aotearoa chapter for more than two decades.

A loyal member, he rose through the ranks and was deputy to his “idol” Joseph “Junior” Wiringi at the time of his death.

He and Kirstyn Beattie, 38, married in 2012.

Iain McGregor/Stuff Kirstyn Beattie becomes emotional when she looks through her wedding album.

They had four children together. Their first, Halo, died in his sleep three months after he was born in 2013.

Beattie said she knew little about the circumstances of the 2015 shooting.

She said she believed her husband knew the identity of the gunman but refused to talk to police because “there’s a code”.

“I know it sounds crazy to other people but in our life … you don’t talk to the police. It would have been worse off for us if he did.”

Beattie said her “soulmate” was “loyal and genuine”.

Iain McGregor/Stuff Kirstyn Beattie says her husband was much more than a gang member.

“I just want people to know he’s much more than just a gang member that got shot. He loved me and the kids so much. He would do anything for us.”

His death had left a huge hole in her life, she said. She’d spent the last few years as his carer, living on the benefit, and worried about how she would make ends meet.

“It’s really hard that he’s not here. I look at the gate every day waiting for him to come home … but I know he’s not. I know it’s only early but I really don’t know what I’m going to do.”
